info.name: Oracle Identity Cloud Service Factor Enrollment API
info.description:
This API allows the user to enroll in multi-factor authentication (MFA) factors with factor verification.

The MFA factors supported are:

- SMS
- EMAIL
- TOTP
- PUSH

The Bypass Code factor can't be enrolled in using these APIs. A bypass code must be generated by the user using the self-service APIs or having and administrator generate a bypass code for them.

Note:
There are Oracle Identity Cloud Service Factor Enrollment and Factor Verification Postman collections available. Download the collections and example environments with variables from the idcs-factor-enrollment-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-enrollment-api) and the idcs-factor-verification-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-verification-api) within GitHub and import them into a REST client.

item.name: Authentication Factor Enrollment - With Factor Verification
SMS Enrollment

request.description:
This step initiates the user's enrollment in the SMS method. The request example shows the contents of the POST request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}}/factors endpoint: 

Mobile Number in the request is the mobile number that the user wants to enroll in for the SMS factor.

The response contains:

- the requestState that should be passed by the client in the next step.
- the displayName of the device being enrolled
- a list of the method(s) being enrolled in
- the factorID that needs to be used when resending the OTP and when activating the SMS factor.

Success indicates that:

- The userGUID that was provided is valid
- The user is active
- The user account isn't locked
- The SMS factor is enabled

response.name: Step 1 Success Response: Enrolling in SMS

header.name: Cache-control
header.description: Tells all caching mechanisms from server to client whether they may cache this object. It is measured in seconds

header.name: Content-length
header.description: The length of the response body in octets (8-bit bytes)

header.name: Content-type
header.description: The mime type of this content

header.name: Date
header.description: The date and time that the message was sent

header.name: Expires
header.description: Gives the date/time after which the response is considered stale

header.name: Pragma
header.description: Implementation-specific headers that may have various effects anywhere along the request-response chain.

header.name: Proxy-agent
header.description: Custom header

header.name: Proxy-agent
header.description: Custom header

header.name: Server
header.description: A name for the server

header.name: Via
header.description: Informs the client of proxies through which the response was sent.

header.name: X-content-type-options
header.description: The only defined value, "nosniff", prevents Internet Explorer from MIME-sniffing a response away from the declared content-type

header.name: X-oracle-dms-ecid
header.description: Custom header

header.name: X-oracle-dms-rid
header.description: Custom header

header.name: X-xss-protection
header.description: Cross-site scripting (XSS) filter

request.description:
If the user doesn't receive the OTP, this example shows how to request that an OTP be resent.

The response contains:

- the requestState that should be passed by the client in the next step.
- the displayName of the device being enrolled
- the list of method(s) being enrolled in
- the factorID.

Success indicates that:

- The userGUID that was provided is valid
- The user is active
- The user account isn't locked
- The SMS factor is enabled

request.description:
This step activates the user’s SMS enrollment in a PATCH request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}}/factors/{{factorID}} endpoint.

The client must include the following attributes:

- otpCode: the code received by the user on their device
- requestState: received in the Step 1 response
- factorID: received in the Step 1 response

Success indicates that:

- OTP is valid
- userGUID is valid
- User is active
- User account isn't locked
- SMS factor is enabled

response.name: Response to Step 2: Activating the SMS Factor

item.description:
The examples in this folder walk you through the requests required for a user to enroll in the SMS factor and includes the factor verification step. 

Factor enrollment is a 2-step process. You first need to initiate, and then activate the factor enrollment.

Note:
There are Oracle Identity Cloud Service Factor Enrollment and Factor Verification Postman collections available. Download the collections and example environments with variables from the idcs-factor-enrollment-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-enrollment-api) and the idcs-factor-verification-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-verification-api) within GitHub and import them into a REST client. 

These steps assume that MFA is enabled and a sign-on policy is created for MFA. See the Configuring Multi-Factor Authentication Settings section in the Oracle Identity Cloud Service Administrator's Guide.

item.name: EMAIL Enrollment

request.description:
This step initiates the user's enrollment in the EMAIL method.

The request example shows the contents of the POST request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}}/factors endpoint: 

The emailID is taken from the user's profile.

The response contains:

- the requestState that should be passed by the client in the next step.
- the displayName (emailId) that is being enrolled in
- a list of the method(s) being enrolled in

Success indicates that:

- The userGUID that was provided is valid
- The user is active
- The user account isn't locked
- The EMAIL factor is enabled

response.name: Response to Step 1: Enrolling in EMAIL

request.description:
Use this request after Step 1 if the user hasn't received the time-based one-time passocde (TOTP) in an email.

The response always contains the requestState that should be passed by the client in the next step.

The response contains the displayName of the device being enrolled, lists the methods being enrolled in, and includes the factorID.

request.description:
This step activates the user’s EMAIL enrollment in a PATCH request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}}/factors/{{factorID}} endpoint.

The client must include the following attributes:

- otpCode: the code received by the user
- requestState: received in the Step 1 response
- factorID: received in the Step 1 response

Success indicates that:

- OTP is valid
- userGUID is valid
- User is active
- User account isn't locked
- EMAIL factor is enabled

item.description:
The examples in this folder walk you through the requests required for a user to enroll in the EMAIL factor and includes the factor verification step. 

Factor enrollment is a 2-step process. You first need to initiate, and then activate the factor enrollment.

Note:
There are Oracle Identity Cloud Service Factor Enrollment and Factor Verification Postman collections available. Download the collections and example environments with variables from the idcs-factor-enrollment-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-enrollment-api) and the idcs-factor-verification-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-verification-api) within GitHub and import them into a REST client. 

These steps assume that MFA is enabled and a sign-on policy is created for MFA. See the Configuring Multi-Factor Authentication Settings section in the Oracle Identity Cloud Service Administrator's Guide.

item.name: Offline TOTP Enrollment

request.description:
This step initiates the user's enrollment in the Offline TOTP method. The request example shows the contents of the POST request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}}/factors endpoint.

The offlineTOTP attribute is set to true in the request.

The response contains:

- the requestState that should be passed by the client in the next step.
- the displayName of the device being enrolled
- a list of the method(s) being enrolled in
- the factorID that needs to be used when resending the TOTP and when activating the Offline TOTP factor.

The QrCode content value in the response contains the QR code information in plain text and the base64 encoded image data that needs to be rendered by the client.

Success indicates that:

- The userGUID that was provided is valid
- The user is active
- The user account isn't locked
- The TOTP factor is enabled

response.name: Response to Step 1: Enrolling in Offline TOTP

item.description:
The examples in this folder walk you through the requests required for a user to enroll in the Offline TOTP factor and includes the factor verification step. 

Factor enrollment is a 2-step process. You first need to initiate, and then activate the factor enrollment.

To get a QR Code to scan for testing purposes:
You must copy the value of the qrCode "content" and use an online QR Code Generator (such as: https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com) to generate a QR Code to scan.

Note:
There are Oracle Identity Cloud Service Factor Enrollment and Factor Verification Postman collections available. Download the collections and example environments with variables from the idcs-factor-enrollment-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-enrollment-api) and the idcs-factor-verification-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-verification-api) within GitHub and import them into a REST client. 

These steps assume that MFA is enabled and a sign-on policy is created for MFA. See the Configuring Multi-Factor Authentication Settings section in the Oracle Identity Cloud Service Administrator's Guide.

item.name: Online TOTP Enrollment

request.description:
This step initiates the user's enrollment in the Online TOTP method. The request example shows the contents of the POST request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}}/factors endpoint.

The response contains:

- the requestState that should be passed by the client in the next step.
- the displayName of the device being enrolled
- a list of the method(s) being enrolled in
- the factorID that needs to be used when resending the TOTP and when activating the Online TOTP factor.

The QrCode content value in the response contains the QR code information in plain text and the base64 encoded image data that needs to be rendered by the client.

Success indicates that:

- The userGUID that was provided is valid
- The user is active
- The user account isn't locked
- The TOTP factor is enabled

item.description:
The examples in this folder walk you through the requests required for a user to enroll in the Online TOTP factor and includes the factor verification step. 

Factor enrollment is a 2-step process. You first need to initiate, and then activate the factor enrollment.

To get a QR Code to scan for testing purposes:
You must copy the value of the qrCode "content" and use an online QR Code Generator (such as: https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com) to generate a QR Code to scan.

These steps assume that MFA is enabled and a sign-on policy is created for MFA. See the Configuring Multi-Factor Authentication Settings section in the Oracle Identity Cloud Service Administrator's Guide.

item.name: PUSH Notification Enrollment

request.description:
This step initiates the user's enrollment in the PUSH Notification method. The request example shows the contents of the POST request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}}/factors endpoint.

Note: When a user chooses to enroll in PUSH notifications, the user is also automatically enrolled in the TOTP factor.

The response contains:

- the requestState that should be passed by the client in the next step.
- the displayName of the device being enrolled
- a list of the method(s) being enrolled in
- the factorID that needs to be used when resending the TOTP and when activating the PUSH Notification factor.

The QrCode content value in the response contains the QR code information in plain text and the base64 encoded image data that needs to be rendered by the client.

Success indicates that:

- The userGUID that was provided is valid
- The user is active
- The user account isn't locked
- The PUSH factor is enabled

response.name: Success Reponse to Step 1: Enrolling in PUSH Notifications

item.description:
The examples in this folder walk you through the requests required for a user to enroll in the PUSH Notification factor and includes the factor verification step. 

Factor enrollment is a 2-step process. You first need to initiate, and then activate the factor enrollment.

To get a QR Code to scan for testing purposes:
You must copy the value of the qrCode "content" and use an online QR Code Generator (such as: https://www.the-qrcode-generator.com) to generate a QR Code to scan.

Note:
There are Oracle Identity Cloud Service Factor Enrollment and Factor Verification Postman collections available. Download the collections and example environments with variables from the idcs-factor-enrollment-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-enrollment-api) and the idcs-factor-verification-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-verification-api) within GitHub and import them into a REST client. 

These steps assume that MFA is enabled and a sign-on policy is created for MFA. See the Configuring Multi-Factor Authentication Settings section in the Oracle Identity Cloud Service Administrator's Guide.

This API allows the user to enroll in multi-factor authentication (MFA) factors with factor verification.

The MFA factors supported are:

- SMS
- EMAIL
- TOTP
- PUSH

The Bypass Code factor can't be enrolled in using these APIs. A bypass code must be generated by the user using the self-service APIs or having and administrator generate a bypass code for them.

Note:
There are Oracle Identity Cloud Service Factor Enrollment and Factor Verification Postman collections available. Download the collections and example environments with variables from the idcs-factor-enrollment-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-enrollment-api) and the idcs-factor-verification-api folder (https://github.com/oracle/idm-samples/tree/master/idcs-factor-verification-api) within GitHub and import them into a REST client.

request.description:
This is an example of how to change a user's default factor. The request example shows the contents of the PATCH request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}} endpoint: 

In the request, the client must include:

- the preferredFactorId: the factorId for the factor 
- the preferredMethod: PUSH/TOTP/SMS/EMAIL

Success indicates that:

- The userGUID is valid
- The user has enrolled in MFA
- The user is active
- The user account isn't locked

response.name: Response for Change Default Factor or Disable a Factor

request.description:
This is an example of using the Oracle Identity Cloud Service On-Demand MFA API to remove a factor. The end user or an admin can choose to delete one enrolled factor for a user.

The request example shows the contents of the PATCH request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}} endpoint.

In the request, the client must provide:

- the factorId for the factor that you want to remove
- the userGUID of the user

response.name: Success Response for Remove User Factor

request.description:
This is an example of using the Oracle Identity Cloud Service On-Demand MFA API to un-enroll a user from Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA).

The request example shows the contents of the PATCH request to the /mfa/v1/users/{{userGUID}} endpoint. 

In the request, the client must set the disableMFA attribute to true.
